questions.question_text: A network administrator is brute forcing accounts through a web interface. Which of the following would provide the BEST defense from an account password being discovered?

discussion.content:
×
account lockout > brute force
password history> prevents reuse
password complexity> characters
password expiration> protects against compromised accounts

comments.content: NO matter complexity, if they have unlimited attempts, they might actually succeed! Now matter how INcomplex, if they only have 1 try before they are locked out for 10 years, they likely wont break password! B is correct!

discussion.content: B - Deceptive question - by stating "network administrator" it implies a legitimate act. But the question actually implies that this is an attack, trying to find a login and password that will provide access to the system. So the best defense is an Account Lockout policy set to a low number which will disable an account when the number is exceeded.

Brute force attacks rely on attempting multiple passwords and accounts. By restricting login attempts to a small amount per user, attackers won’t be able to try more than a few passwords.

A common way to restrict login attempts is to temporarily ban an IP from logging in after five failed login attempts, where subsequent attempts

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a major difference between XSS attacks and remote code exploits?

comments.content: I feel the same way as well. I have a pdf that shows the answer to this question is C.

discussion.content: XSS doesn’t use machine language at all... but none of the other answers seem correct. I would say C, but it’s also wrong. Questions like these make me hate comptia

comments.content: This man got 95% right as he explained his insights on the exam on the 501 exam overview page...I highly recommend looking for his comments and following his advice. It has helped me a lot on these nonsensical 50/50 questions
Duranio said in another topic that he got 825 IIRC on his test.
Can't be B, because XSS is client-side while remote code execution is server-side.

discussion.content:
This was on my exam (5 Aug 2020).
XSS does not use "machine language" but high level programming languages like javascript, so answer A is absolutely wrong.
XSS DOES require code to work, so answer D is absolutely wrong.

Answers B and C are poorly worded and depending on how you interpret them they are both partially correct and partially wrong. Anyway at the end I chose answer C. I passed my exam but still, onestly, I can't garantee this answer is correct. In particular the part "XSS attacks aim to gain access only" sounds really odd to me; I have done some kind of XSS attacks, and my aim wasn't "to gain access" (access to what?). If C is really the right answer, once again CompTIA authors can be proud of their orrible job.
yes, choice C is definitely correct,

It is important to make it clear that RCE is different from the XSS vulnerability found in OWASP Top 10, even though it is also a code injection vulnerability.

The basic difference is that RCE is a vulnerability that exploits a server-side fragility, meaning that the code sent will be executed on the server-side. RCE attacks vary in shape and form. An attacker can simply execute malicious code on your machine to achieve a specific purpose, but an RCE attack can also mean that an attacker takes full and complete control of your device – including accessing applications and services using elevated privileges.

In XSS, for example, the code used exploits a client-side weakness, usually using the user’s browser to return the desired data or information.

Based on that I will go with C.
i dont know what the answer is but i know its at A. XSS uses JS mostly
Same question was in 31-1-2021

It does not say that xss only use the machine language, you can use visual Basic to launch xss attack and it is a machine language , so it could definitely be A, since it does not say that it ONLY uses machine language
it is C

I think the answer is C. XSS is a client-side vulnerability which the attacker wants to gain access and perform other malicious things:
Impersonate or masquerade as the victim user.
Carry out any action that the user is able to perform.
Read any data that the user is able to access.
Capture the user's login credentials.
Perform virtual defacement of the web site.
Inject trojan functionality into the web site.

In addition, here are the differences between RCE and XSS:
The basic difference is that RCE is a vulnerability that exploits a server-side fragility, meaning that the code sent will be executed on the server-side.

In XSS, for example, the code used exploits a client-side weakness, usually using the user’s browser to return the desired data or information.
Definite C

I will go with C as well since remote code exploits are combining with privilege escalation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitrary_code_execution) and ... malicious content can access sensitive information on the client, including content and session cookie information. ... (Mike Meyers’ CompTIA Security+ p. 435)
i can never imagine how did the "use machine language" thing come out as an answer.
Correct answer is C.
quizlet shows C as well.
Just checked two other sites and they agree that it is C.
Correct Answer: C (Not B) XSS attacks the victim's Web browser. (Not A) neither uses machine language. (Not D) they both require code to execute.

Not A.
programming languages, like C++, Java, or Visual Basic. A computer cannot directly understand the programming languages used to create computer programs, so the program code must be compiled. Once a program's code is compiled, the computer can understand it because the program's code is turned into machine language.

"Cross-site scripting (XSS) is another web application vulnerability that
can be prevented with input validation techniques. Attackers embed malicious
HTML or JavaScript code into a web site’s code."
Neither Javascript nor HTML is a machine language.
"JavaScript is an interpreted language, not a compiled language."
"HTML is not a programming language, there's a reason why it's called hyper text markup language. ... HTML is not complied into into machine language as it does not execute instructions"

"In XSS attacks, malicious content is delivered to users using JavaScript." Isn't Java machine language?
What do you think now?

comments.content: Java and JavaScript are not the same thing. JS is run in the web browser.
Java isn't machine language at all
Machine language is like binary...1s and 0s

discussion.content: Gonna have to go with C on this one chief.

choices.D: Remote code exploits allow writing code at the client side and executing it, while XSS attacks require no code to work
choices.C: Remote code exploits aim to escalate attackers' privileges, while XSS attacks aim to gain access only
choices.B: XSS attacks target servers, while remote code exploits target clients
choices.A: XSS attacks use machine language, while remote exploits use interpreted language

choices.B: The deny statement for 204.211.38.52/24 should be changed to a permit statement
choices.D: The permit statement for 204.211.38.211/24 should be changed to TCP port 631 only instead of ALL
choices.A: The permit statement for 204.211.38.52/24 should be changed to TCP port 631 instead of UDP
choices.C: The permit statement for 204.211.38.52/24 should be changed to UDP port 443 instead of 631

comments.content: I cannot find information about port 631 in the book that I use.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Printing_Protocol

"IPP uses TCP with port 631 as its well-known port."

discussion.content: I think the answer is correct, port 631 is for printing, but it should be TCP not UDP.

choices.E: Require the web server to only use TLS 1.2 encryption
choices.C: Force users to change passwords the next time they log on
choices.D: Limit users to five attempted logons before they are locked out
choices.A: Start using salts to generate MD5 password hashes

questions.question_text:
A security analyst is doing a vulnerability assessment on a database server. A scanning tool returns the following information:
//IMG//

There have been several security breaches on the web server that accesses this database. The security team is instructed to mitigate the impact of any possible breaches. The security team is also instructed to improve the security on this database by making it less vulnerable to offline attacks. Which of the following would
BEST accomplish these goals? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Salting would strengthen the security, and since there have been prior breaches the existing password may be compromised and should be changed at next logon. ~ 2 cents
A and C are both offline security improvements and it is suited well for defending offline attacks.

comments.content:
I feel the key here is "making it less vulnerable to OFFLINE attacks". Rainbow attack is often done in an offline manner by precomputing the corresponding hashes. A rainbow table attack is only possible because the output of a hash function is always the same with the same input. However, if we add random data to the end of the password (salting), it is unlikely to recover the password using precomputed hash since it gets only the password, not the password + salting. 

Although SHA-256 is more secure than MD5, salting seems to be a more appropriate answer for this question.
We still need Salt, yes SHA is more secure but we need to salt the password hashes and answer A is the only one that has SALT as an option.

discussion.content: Why not B & D? Using SHA would be more secure then MD5 and locking the user out after failed attempts would increase security.
